content:
De Novo Transcriptome Assembly: RNA-seq Without Reference

Reconstruct complete transcriptomes from bulk RNA-seq data without requiring a reference genome. This comprehensive pipeline performs end-to-end analysis from raw paired-end reads to annotated transcript assemblies, making it essential for non-model organism research and novel transcript discovery.

What is De Novo Transcriptome Assembly?

De novo assembly reconstructs RNA transcripts directly from sequencing reads without relying on a reference genome. This approach is crucial when studying organisms without high-quality genome assemblies or when discovering novel transcripts, isoforms, and expressed sequences.

Key Features

  • Multiple Assemblers: Choose between Trinity and rnaSPAdes, or run both
  • Normalization Options: Trinity supports normalized and non-normalized assembly
  • Comprehensive QC: FastQC for reads, BUSCO for completeness, TransRate for quality
  • Contamination Removal: Optional rRNA and mitochondrial DNA filtering
  • Redundancy Reduction: Evidential Gene removes redundant transcripts
  • Expression Quantification: Salmon for fast, accurate transcript abundance

Pipeline Workflow

  1. Read Quality Control: FastQC assessment of raw sequencing data
  2. Adapter Trimming: fastp removes adapters and low-quality bases
  3. rRNA Removal: Optional SortMeRNA filtering (recommended)
  4. De Novo Assembly: Trinity or rnaSPAdes reconstruction of transcripts
  5. Redundancy Reduction: Evidential Gene tr2aacds filters redundant sequences
  6. Quality Assessment: BUSCO completeness, TransRate metrics, rnaQUAST statistics
  7. Quantification: Salmon pseudo-alignment and abundance estimation
  8. Comprehensive Reporting: MultiQC summary of all metrics

Assembly Methods

Trinity (Default)

  • Approach: De Bruijn graph-based assembly with Inchworm, Chrysalis, and Butterfly modules
  • Strengths: Excellent for complex transcriptomes, isoform detection, widely validated
  • Options: Normalized (faster, reduces redundancy) or non-normalized (more comprehensive)
  • Best for: High-quality assemblies, alternative splicing studies, eukaryotic transcriptomes

rnaSPAdes

  • Approach: SPAdes assembler optimized for transcriptome data
  • Strengths: Fast, memory-efficient, handles uneven coverage well
  • Filtering Levels: Multiple stringency options for transcript filtering
  • Best for: Large datasets, prokaryotic/viral transcriptomes, rapid assembly

Quality Assessment Tools

  • BUSCO: Benchmarking Universal Single-Copy Orthologs - measures assembly completeness
  • TransRate: Reference-free assembly quality metrics including read support
  • rnaQUAST: Comprehensive transcriptome assembly evaluation
  • Salmon Mapping Rate: Percentage of reads mapping back to assembly

Input Requirements

Samplesheet Format (CSV):

sample,fastq_1,fastq_2
sample1,sample1_R1.fastq.gz,sample1_R2.fastq.gz
sample2,sample2_R1.fastq.gz,sample2_R2.fastq.gz
sample3,sample3_R1.fastq.gz,sample3_R2.fastq.gz

Requirements:

  • Paired-end reads: FASTQ format, gzip compressed (.fastq.gz)
  • Quality: Standard Illumina sequencing (>Q30 for majority of bases)
  • Depth: 20-40 million read pairs recommended for comprehensive assembly
  • Multiple samples: Can be pooled for assembly or assembled separately

Main Outputs

Transcriptome Assembly

  • Assembled transcripts: FASTA file with complete transcriptome
  • Filtered assembly: Redundancy-reduced, high-quality transcript set
  • Assembly metrics: N50, total transcripts, total length, GC content

Quality Control

  • BUSCO scores: Completeness percentages (Complete, Fragmented, Missing)
  • TransRate metrics: Read support, contig quality, segmentation scores
  • MultiQC report: Comprehensive HTML summary of all QC metrics

Expression Data

  • Salmon quantification: TPM (Transcripts Per Million) values for each transcript
  • Count matrices: Raw and normalized expression counts
  • Mapping statistics: Alignment rates and concordance metrics

Scientific Applications

  • Non-Model Organisms: Study species without reference genomes
  • Novel Transcript Discovery: Identify unannotated genes and isoforms
  • Comparative Transcriptomics: Compare gene expression across species
  • Functional Genomics: Annotate genes and predict functions
  • Evolutionary Studies: Analyze transcript evolution and conservation
  • Environmental Samples: Transcriptomics of complex communities
  • Crop Improvement: Agricultural genomics for non-sequenced varieties

When to Use This Pipeline

Choose de novo assembly when:

  • No reference genome is available for your organism
  • Reference genome quality is poor or incomplete
  • Discovering novel genes, transcripts, or isoforms
  • Studying rapidly evolving species or populations
  • Working with environmental or metagenomic RNA samples
  • Investigating organisms with complex genomes (polyploidy, high repeats)

Best Practices

  • rRNA Removal: Always enable for eukaryotic samples (reduces assembly complexity)
  • Read Depth: Use 30-50M read pairs for comprehensive transcriptome coverage
  • Read Quality: Ensure high-quality sequencing (Q30+ for 90%+ bases)
  • Multiple Samples: Pool biological replicates for better assembly completeness
  • Normalization: Use Trinity normalization for very deep sequencing (>100M reads)
  • BUSCO Lineage: Select appropriate lineage database for accurate completeness assessment
  • Downstream Annotation: Use assembled transcripts with Trinotate or eggNOG-mapper

Comparison: De Novo vs Reference-Based

FeatureDe Novo AssemblyReference-Based
Reference Genome❌ Not required✅ Required
Novel Transcripts✅ Discovers all⚠️ Limited
Computational Cost⚠️ High (CPU/RAM intensive)✅ Lower
Assembly Accuracy⚠️ More challenging✅ Higher
Runtime⚠️ Hours to days✅ Minutes to hours
Best forNon-model organismsWell-studied species

Technical Requirements

  • Memory: 100-200GB RAM recommended (depends on read depth and assembler)
  • CPUs: 32-64 cores for optimal performance
  • Storage: 100-500GB for intermediate files and results
  • Runtime: 6-24 hours typical (varies by dataset size and assembler)

Perfect for Research in: Non-model organisms • Novel gene discovery • Evolutionary genomics • Functional annotation • Comparative transcriptomics • Agricultural genomics • Environmental biology • Emerging model systems
